questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackievirus

 

The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

 

Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents.

 

Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus:

 

  • Aseptic meningitis associated with a maculopapular rash.
  • Herpangina
  • Minor respiratory infections

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Human herpes virus 7: Associated with roseola infantum, not HFMD.

 

Option C. Pox virus: Causes diseases like smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, characterized by different types of lesions.

 

Option D. Molluscum contagiosum: Causes dome-shaped, pearly lesions with central umbilication, distinct from HFMD vesicles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Coxsackievirus is the causative agent of hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa.

 

Palms and Soles rash is seen in – CARS

 

  1. Coxsackievirus A16
  2. Rocky mountain spotted fever
  3. Secondary Syphilis

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: Associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.

questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that is often found intracellularly within neutrophils. It is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections, including infections of the Bartholin glands. The typical presentation includes swelling and pus discharge, which is consistent with the given clinical scenario.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is characterized by its kidney or bean shape and lack of a capsule, unlike Neisseria meningitidis, which is capsulated. It is known for causing sexually transmitted infections, including those affecting the genital tract, such as Bartholin gland abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Although Chlamydia can cause genital infections, it is not a Gram-negative diplococcus. Instead, it is an obligate intracellular bacterium with a unique developmental cycle.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, chancroid is a Gram-negative bacillus and not a diplococcus.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete, which is not a Gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative intracellular diplococcus, is the causative agent of gonorrhea and can infect the Bartholin glands, leading to swelling and pus discharge.

questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlorine compound

 

Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

 

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenolic compound: Phenolic compounds are effective disinfectants but are generally less effective against a broad spectrum of bloodborne pathogens compared to chlorine compounds.

 

Option C. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Quaternary ammonium compounds are good for general disinfection but are not recommended for blood spills as they are less effective against non-enveloped viruses and spores.

 

Option D. Alcoholic compounds: Alcohol-based disinfectants are effective for surface disinfection but are not ideal for blood spills as they can coagulate proteins, making blood more difficult to clean.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cleaning a blood spill in the operation theatre, sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant due to its effectiveness in inactivating a wide range of pathogens and its suitability for such critical environments.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: A patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), who has had a urinary catheter in place for three weeks, presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI). The catheter tip is sent for culture on blood agar. After 24 hours, the culture displays a unique swarming growth pattern. Which of the following microorganisms is the most likely cause of this infection? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Proteus mirabilis

 

Explanation:

 

Proteus mirabilis is a gram-negative bacterium known for its characteristic "swarming" motility on solid media, such as blood agar. This swarming pattern is due to the bacteria's peritrichous flagella, which allow for rapid and coordinated movement across the agar surface. This unique motility pattern, combined with the patient's clinical history (BPH and long-term catheterization), strongly suggests Proteus mirabilis as the causative agent of the CAUTI.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Escherichia coli: While E. coli is a common cause of UTIs, it does not exhibit the characteristic swarming motility seen on blood agar.
  • Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: K. pneumoniae is another common UTI pathogen, but it typically forms mucoid colonies and does not swarm on blood agar.
  • Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: P. aeruginosa is a less common cause of CAUTIs and typically produces pigmented colonies with a distinct odor. It does not exhibit swarming motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of swarming motility on blood agar is a hallmark of Proteus mirabilis and is a strong indicator of this organism as the causative agent in cases of suspected catheter-associated urinary tract infections.

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

 

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophila, previously known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
  • It displays susceptibility to cotrimoxazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proteus mirabilis:

 

  • Resistant to: Nitrofurantoin, Tetracyclines
  • Susceptible to aminoglycosides, carbapenems, cephalosporins, cotromoxazole, penicillin+ β-lactamase inhibitors.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, especially in cystic fibrosis patients, and opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

 

  • Known for resistance to multiple antibiotics, but typically not specifically resistant to meropenem.
  • Susceptible to: A wide range of antibiotics, often including aminoglycosides, depending on the strain.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, wound infections, and urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Acinetobacter baumannii:

 

  • Known for multi-drug resistance, including to carbapenems like meropenem.
  • Susceptibility varies, but generally not as consistently susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate as Stenotrophomonas maltophila.
  • Clinical manifestations: Hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and bloodstream infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10-30 days

 

The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days.

 

The causative agent is Chlamydia trachomatis, serovars L1, L2, L3. Chlamydia is a ubiquitous ovoid or obligate intracellular bacteria.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum primarily affects the lymphatic system. Chlamydia trachomatis serovars extend from the primary infection site to the regional lymph nodes and cause a lymphoproliferative reaction, facilitated by binding of Chlamydia trachomatis to the epithelial cells. Binding occurs via heparin sulfate receptors.

 

The basis for a definitive diagnosis of LGV is on serology tests (complement fixation or micro-immunofluorescence) or identification of Chlamydia trachomatis in genital, rectal and lymph node specimens (by culture, nucleic acid amplification test or direct immunofluorescence).

 

Educational Objective

 

The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is 10-30 days. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3, and primarily affects the lymphatic system. Diagnosis is based on serological tests or identification of the bacteria in clinical specimens through various methods.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

 

Explanation:

 

XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.

 

Option C. Ebola: Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.

 

Option D. Congo Crimean Fever: Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique is '2'.

 

 

The sandwich ELISA is a type of Enzyme-linked immunosorbent Assay that uses two antibodies: a capture antibody and a detection antibody. It is called a sandwich because your antigen is bound between antibodies. The purpose of any ELISA is to detect the presence of a target antigen in a sample. In a sandwich ELISA the target antigen is bound between a capture antibody and a detection antibody. The capture antibody is immobilized on a surface, while the detection antibody (conjugated to an enzyme or fluorophore label) is applied as a last step before quantitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Represents the substrate that produces a detectable signal when reacted with the enzyme.

 

Option C. 3: Represents the primary detection antibody that binds to the antigen.

 

Option D. 4: Represents the capture antibody that is immobilized on the surface and captures the antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the sandwich ELISA technique, the enzyme conjugate is part of the detection antibody, which binds to the antigen and, upon addition of a substrate, produces a detectable signal. In this diagram, '2' is identified as the enzyme conjugate.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex

 

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infection

 

The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HS, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Incorrect, as Rabies is associated with Negri bodies, which are specific cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Incorrect, as this condition is linked to Henderson-Peterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option D. Adenovirus: Incorrect for Cowdry Type A inclusions; however, Cowdry type C basophilic inclusions are seen in Adenovirus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:

Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans
Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

 

The given image shows hymenolepis nana egg. Egg is spherical or ovoid and has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar. Filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest and the most common tapeworm found in the human intestine.

 

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. There are usually no symptoms but in heavy infections, there is nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

 

Praziquantel (single dose of 25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice, since it acts both against the adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide 500 mg BD for 3 days may be used as alternative.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albendazole is the drug of choice: This is incorrect. The drug of choice for Hymenolepis nana is praziquantel (a single dose of 25 mg/kg) because it acts against both adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide (500 mg BD for 3 days) may be used as an alternative.

 

Option C. Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants: This is incorrect. The infection with Hymenolepis nana is not acquired through aquatic plants. Infections are usually acquired by ingestion of contaminated food or water or by autoinfection.

 

Option D. Non-segmented leaf-like parasite: This is incorrect. Hymenolepis nana is a segmented tapeworm, not a non-segmented leaf-like parasite.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the most common and smallest tapeworm in humans. Majority of infections are asymptomatic. The drug of choice is praziquantel.

 

Parasites with aquatic plants as the source of infection:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Watsonius watsoni
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents to her obstetrician for a routine check-up. She reports mild flu-like symptoms, including low-grade fever, muscle aches, and fatigue over the past week. She mentions that she has recently been cleaning her cat’s litter box frequently. Given her symptoms and history, the physician considers the risk of a particular parasitic infection. Based on the lifecycle depicted in the image below, identify the organism responsible for her condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Toxoplasma gondii

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis. Cats, members of the Felidae family, are the definitive hosts where the enteric cycle occurs. The parasite's lifecycle involves the shedding of unsporulated oocysts in cat feces, which become infective within 1-5 days. Intermediate hosts, including humans, birds, and rodents, become infected upon ingestion of sporulated oocysts from contaminated environments. In humans, T. gondii can form tissue cysts in various organs, such as muscle and brain, which may remain latent throughout life. This infection can be particularly concerning during pregnancy due to the risk of transplacental transmission to the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium falciparum: This parasite causes malaria and is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. Its lifecycle primarily involves humans and mosquitoes, not involving cats or fecal-oral transmission, making it unrelated to the lifecycle depicted.

 

Option C. Giardia lamblia: Giardia causes gastrointestinal infections, primarily spread through contaminated water and food. It does not involve a definitive feline host or a lifecycle involving oocysts, as seen in Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Option D. Entamoeba histolytica: This parasite causes amebiasis, leading to dysentery and liver abscesses, primarily through the fecal-oral route involving contaminated water. Its lifecycle does not involve cats or the formation of tissue cysts as seen with Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a lifecycle involving definitive feline hosts and intermediate hosts, including humans. Transmission occurs through ingestion of sporulated oocysts from contaminated sources or undercooked meat. Infections can be particularly dangerous during pregnancy, leading to transplacental transmission and congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is another helminth with a similar skin-penetrating infection method, but its life cycle is characterized by direct development into adult worms in the intestine after migration, without a free-living phase.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: This helminth has a different life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which then hatch in the intestine, and larvae migrate through the liver and lungs before maturing in the intestine.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Known as pinworm, this helminth has a life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which hatch in the intestine, and the adult worms live in the colon and rectum.

 

Educational Objective:


Strongyloides stercoralis infects through skin penetration by filariform larvae from contaminated soil.

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

 

A Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear shows many red blood cells (RBCs) infected with classic, ring-shaped and headphone-shaped trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum parasite. High degree of parasitemia and RBCs infected with two or more trophozoites were seen, a finding typical of P. falciparum malaria.

 

Cerebral malaria is a complicated form of malaria associated with multisystem organ dysfunction and high degree of morbidity and mortality. These patients often present with impaired consciousness, delirium and convulsions. It is a medical emergency where prompt diagnosis and early institution of treatment can be lifesaving. Intravenous quinine or artesunate are the mainstays of treatment in cerebral malaria.

 

Management of Cerebral Malaria:

 

  • Artesunate: Administered intravenously at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg immediately, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then once daily if necessary.
  • Alternative Treatment:
    • Artemether: 3.2 mg/kg intramuscularly initially, followed by 1.6 mg/kg once daily.
    • Quinine dihydrochloride: 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2-8 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg intravenously for 7 days: Doxycycline is not the first-line treatment for severe malaria. It is typically used as a secondary prophylactic measure or in combination with other antimalarial drugs.

 

Option B. Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days: Clindamycin is not used for the treatment of malaria. It is an antibiotic that is used for bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Chloroquine intramuscularly 8 hourly for 3 days: Chloroquine is ineffective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance. It is also not suitable for treating severe or cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

choices.text: Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin
Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin
Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining and microscopy and appears as shown in the microscopic image given below. Which of the following features/tests will be characteristic of the organism? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catalase negative, optochin sensitive

 

This image is a light micrograph of Gram-stained S. pneumoniae (also known as S. pneumococcus), rounded bacteria (cocci) that usually occur in pairs and sometimes short chains. Their blue color indicates they are Gram-positive.

 

Meningitis occurs when bacteria enter the bloodstream and then cross the blood-brain barrier or through direct contact of meninges with the skin or nasal cavity. The most frequent focus of the infection is the nasopharynx colonized by S. pneumoniae that evades the host immune system. During IPD, the bloodstream becomes invaded, and complement and coagulation systems are activated. Inflammatory mediators are released massively, which makes it easier for the bacteria to cross the blood-brain barrier. Inflammation is responsible for all the typical findings of bacterial meningitis, i.e., CSF pleocytosis.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin: This description is not characteristic of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Oxidase-negative and catalase-negative bacteria include many streptococci, but inulin fermentation is not a typical test used for identifying S. pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin: This characteristic fits some Neisseria species but not S. pneumoniae. S. pneumoniae ferments glucose and sometimes other carbohydrates but is best identified by its optochin sensitivity and bile solubility.

 

Option C. Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose: This describes certain gram-negative bacteria, such as Neisseria species, which do not fit the description of S. pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of bacterial meningitis, is characterized by being catalase-negative, optochin-sensitive, and gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci. These features help in its identification and differentiation from other bacterial pathogens.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is elevated in a case of chronic allergy? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgE

 

Immunoglobulin E (IgE) is specifically associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections. In the context of chronic allergies, such as asthma, hay fever, and other allergic conditions, IgE levels are typically elevated. IgE binds to allergens and triggers histamine release from mast cells and basophils, leading to the symptoms of allergic reactions.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is primarily found in mucous membranes, secretions like tears, saliva, and colostrum, and plays a critical role in mucosal immunity.

 

Option B. IgM: IgM is the main antibody of primary immune responses and is effective at fixing complement. It is also found as a monomer on the surface of B cells.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is the most abundant antibody in blood and extracellular fluid, providing the majority of antibody-based immunity against invading pathogens. It is the main antibody involved in secondary immune responses and can cross the placenta.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

 

The above lesion is most likely caused by  Sporothrix schencki (S. schenckii)

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. In its saprophytic stage or when cultured at 25°C, it assumes a filamentous form, composed of hyaline, septate hyphae 1 to 2 μm wide, with conidiogenous cells arising from undifferentiated hyphae forming conidia in groups on small, clustered denticles. These one-celled conidia are tear shaped to clavate and do not yield chains. The S. schenckii colonies never become cottony or floccose.

Infection with the dimorphic soil fungus S schenckii is usually transmitted by the mold form from organic matter through cutaneous inoculation. The mycosis has also been transmitted from animals through bites or scratches.

 

The initial reddish, necrotic, nodular papule of cutaneous sporotrichosis generally appears 1-10 weeks after a penetrating skin injury. The lesion is a suppurating granuloma that consists of histiocytes and giant cells, with neutrophils that accumulate in the center and that are surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

The fungal infection spreads from the initial lesion along lymphatic channels, forming the chain of indolent nodular and ulcerating lesions typical of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other tissues are involved by direct extension and, less often, by hematogenous dissemination. The most common extracutaneous infection sites are in the bones, joints, tendon sheaths, and bursae. Hematogenous dissemination—particularly in immunocompromised hosts—results in widely disseminated cutaneous and visceral infection, including meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen. It may cause pulmonary disease and local lymphadenitis, primarily in the submandibular and submaxillary regions. It is usually a benign, self-limited condition with no systemic symptoms except for mild neck pain.

 

Option C. Eumyectoma or mycetoma also called as Madura foot, is a chronic subcutaneous granulomatous soft-tissue infection. The etiological agent may be fungal (eumycetoma) or bacterial (actinomycetoma) and appears under microscopic examination as hyphae or thin filaments, respectively. The cardinal features of the disease are tumefaction, sinus formation, and presentation of grains or granules in draining exudate.

 

Option D. Phialophora verrucosa is a common cause of chromoblastomycosis. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. The fungus is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, (known as sclerotic bodies) on histology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obligate intracellular organism

 

Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e, it is a facultative intracellular organism.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is an obligate human pathogen and is the etiological agent of gonorrhea.

 

Habitat –

 

  • Human is only the natural host.
  • Found in human urogenital tract.
  • Rectal carriage in healthy individuals.
  • Typically seen in pus cells (intracellular)
  • Found intracellularly in polymorphonuclear leukocytes, or a specific category of white blood cells with varying shapes of nuclei.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Catalase and oxidase positive: This is true for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which tests positive for both catalase and oxidase enzymes.

 

Option B. Pili is a virulence factor: Neisseria gonorrhoeae has pili on its surface, which are essential for its virulence, aiding in attachment and colonization.

 

Option D. Shows twitching motility: Neisseria gonorrhoeae exhibits twitching motility, a type of bacterial movement.

 

Educational Objective

 

Morphology of Neisseria Gonorrhea -

 

  • Gram –ve cocci
  • Shape is spherical
  • Coffee bean shaped diplococcic
  • Usually seen in pairs with adjacent sides flattened
  • LPS has highly branched basal oligosaccharide structure
  • Contains fimbriae
  • Possess pili on the surface
  • Motile (Twitching motility)
  • Non-capsulated
  • Non-sporing

 

It is catalase and oxidase positive.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

 

Clinical history is suggestive of neurocysticercosis.

 

Causative organism - Larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of T. solium.

 

Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of brain) is the most common and most serious form of cysticercosis. About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis. Other clinical features of neurocysticercosis are increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders, aphasia and visual disturbances. It is considered as the second most common cause of intracranial space occupying lesion (lCSOL) after tuberculosis in India.

 

Treatment –

 

  1. For cysticercosis, excision is the best method, wherever possible.
  2. Asymptomatic neurocysticercosis requires no treatment.
  3. For symptomatic cerebral cysticercosis, praziquantel in a dose of 50 mg/ kg in three divided doses for 20-30 days and albendazole in a dose of 400 mg twice daily for 30 days may be administered.
  4. Corticosteroids may be given along with praziquantel or albendazole to reduce the inflammatory reactions caused by the dead cysticerci.
  5. In addition, antiepileptic drugs should be given until the reaction of the brain has subsided.
  6. Operative intervention is indicated for hydrocephalus

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Antiparasitic drugs followed by steroids: The correct sequence is to give steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs.

 

Option C. Steroids before antiepileptics: While steroids are important, antiepileptics are also necessary to control seizures.

 

Option D. Continue antiepileptics: While antiepileptics are part of the treatment, steroids and antiparasitic drugs are also necessary for managing neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.

choices.text: 55°C for 5 minutes
80°C for 10 minutes
63°C for 30 minutes

questions.text: A food safety inspector is reviewing the pasteurization process at a dairy that has been linked to a recent outbreak of milk-borne illness. During the inspection, he asks the technical staff, "At what temperature and duration is pasteurization typically performed to ensure the safety of milk without significantly altering its taste and nutritional value?"
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 63°C for 30 minutes

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is the Holder method of pasteurization, where milk is heated to 63°C for 30 minutes. This method effectively kills most non-spore-forming pathogens, making milk safe for consumption while preserving its nutritional and sensory qualities. Pasteurization generally involves heating milk at specific temperatures: either 63°C for 30 minutes (Holder method) or 72°C for 15-20 seconds (flash pasteurization). After heating, the milk is rapidly cooled to 13°C or lower to inhibit bacterial growth. These processes eliminate nearly all harmful bacteria, though some heat-resistant organisms like Coxiella burnetti may survive the Holder method. This approach ensures the safety of milk without significantly altering its taste or nutritional value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pasteurization is a critical process used to ensure the safety of milk by killing most non-spore-forming pathogens. The Holder method (63°C for 30 minutes) and flash pasteurization (72°C for 15-20 seconds) are commonly used techniques that effectively reduce microbial load while preserving the quality and taste of milk, although some heat-resistant bacteria may survive these processes.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: Which virus requires reverse transcriptase PCR for detection? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RSV

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is an RNA virus that requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) to convert its RNA into DNA for detection. RT-PCR is a sensitive method used to detect and quantify RNA viruses by first converting their RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using the enzyme reverse transcriptase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses are DNA viruses and do not require reverse transcription. They can be detected using standard PCR methods that amplify their DNA directly.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr Virus is a DNA virus and uses standard PCR for detection. Reverse transcription is not necessary for DNA viruses.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is also a DNA virus and can be detected through standard DNA PCR. Reverse transcription is not needed for its detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RSV, an RNA virus, requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for detection by converting RNA into DNA.

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is a common viral illness caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The disease typically affects young children. It is characterized by a high fever lasting for three to five days, which abruptly resolves and is followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash consists of small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. It is typically nonpruritic, blanching, and can persist from one to two days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

In contrast, petechial rashes are small, pinpoint, red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin and are associated with the following diseases:

 

Option A. Zika Virus: Zika virus infection can cause a mild, dengue-like illness, which includes symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. The rash can be maculopapular, and in some cases, petechiae can be observed.

 

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease: This is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India. It is caused by the Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV) and presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle pain, vomiting, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hemorrhagic manifestations, including petechiae.

 

 

Option D. West Nile Fever: This disease is caused by the West Nile virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, including fever, headache, body aches, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, neurological complications. Petechial rashes can occur in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Cause of death in the position shown in the image below is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positional asphyxia

 

The position shown is Jack-knife position that leads to positional asphyxia (Restriction of lung expansion d/t abnormal position of the body). It is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Wedging: Infant falls in the small gap between wall & bed and getting wedged there. It is a type of traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option B) Burking: Accused sits on chest of victim & closes mouth/ nostril as well. Its Mechanism is smothering combined with traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option D) Traumatic asphyxia: it is asphyxia due to restriction of lung expansion as a result of mechanical fixation of chest and not due to abnormal body position hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of Mechanical Asphyxia

 

1. Suffocation Asphyxia

  • Smothering
  • Gagging
  • Traumatic Asphyxia (Crush Asphyxia)
  • Positional Asphyxia (Postural Asphyxia)
  • Burking
  • Overlaying
  • Choking (Café Coronary)

 

2. Compression of neck

  • Hanging – force is body weight / body is suspended
  • Strangulation – force is anything other than body weight / no suspension.

 

3. Drowning

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine Ca ratio > 0.15

 

Nutritional rickets is a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired bone mineralization and growth. The incorrect statement in the context of nutritional rickets is:

 

This is typically seen in primary hyperparathyroidism, not in secondary hyperparathyroidism like that seen in vitamin D deficiency or nutritional rickets. In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is usually low because of the body's attempt to conserve calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

The following points summarize the key biochemical features of nutritional rickets:

 

Option A. Normal Calcium: In many cases of nutritional rickets, serum calcium levels are normal or low-normal at the time of presentation due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which compensates for the low calcium by increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

Option B. Low Phosphate: Hypophosphatemia is common in rickets due to decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate and increased renal excretion.

 

Option D. High PTH: Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs as a response to hypocalcemia, leading to elevated PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. Elevated PTH, low phosphate, and normal calcium levels are typical biochemical findings in this condition.

choices.text: Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM
Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV
Atropine 3 mg
Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.text: The drug of choice in Anaphylactic Shock is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM

 

Anaphylactic shock is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that requires immediate treatment. The first-line treatment for anaphylactic shock is the administration of adrenaline (epinephrine). Adrenaline works by counteracting the severe hypotension, bronchospasm, and edema that occur during anaphylactic reactions.

 

Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM is the recommended dose for the treatment of anaphylaxis. This intramuscular injection provides rapid absorption and action, which is critical in managing the symptoms of anaphylaxis effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV: This dose and concentration of adrenaline are typically used in cardiac arrest scenarios, not for initial treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Option C. Atropine 3 mg: Atropine is used primarily to treat bradycardia (slow heart rate) and is not effective in managing anaphylactic shock.

 

Option D. Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV: Adenosine is used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and is not relevant for the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Viral culture and isolation in C6/36 cell line
ELISA for detection of dengue virus antibodies
NS1 antigen detection
RT-PCR for dengue virus RNA

questions.text: A patient presents with suspected dengue fever on the third day of illness. Which of the following investigations is LEAST likely to yield a diagnostic result at this stage? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. ELISA for detection of dengue virus antibodies

 

Explanation:

 

In the acute phase of dengue infection (first 5-6 days), the following tests can be used for diagnosis:

 

  • Viral culture and isolation: This method is sensitive but time-consuming, requiring specialized laboratory facilities. It can detect the virus in the early stages of infection.
  • NS1 antigen detection: This test detects a non-structural protein of the dengue virus, which is present in the blood during the early phase of infection (typically within the first week).
  • RT-PCR for dengue virus RNA: This highly sensitive test detects the genetic material of the virus and can provide a rapid diagnosis within the first few days of illness.

 

However, ELISA for antibody detection against the dengue virus is not reliable in the early stages of infection. It takes about 5 days for the body to produce detectable levels of IgM antibodies against the dengue virus. Therefore, ELISA would not be a suitable test for diagnosing dengue on the third day of illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ELISA for dengue antibody detection is not a suitable diagnostic test in the early stages of dengue infection (before day 5). Other tests like viral culture, NS1 antigen detection, and RT-PCR are more appropriate for early diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 drugs for 6 months

 

According to the latest WHO guidelines treatment of multibacillary and paucibacillary leprosy is same except for duration of treatment.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The treatment for paucibacillary leprosy involves a combination of three drugs (rifampin, clofazimine, and dapsone) administered over a period of 6 months.

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

 

Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) scoring system:

 

Other Options:

 

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

 

Option A. Altered mental status

 

Option B. Low blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)

 

Option C. High respiratory rate (>22 breaths per min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.

 

The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.

 

The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.

 

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis, also known as the Chinese liver fluke, is a parasitic worm that infects the bile ducts of the liver. Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis is a well-known risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a type of cancer that occurs in the bile ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular cancer: This is commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B and C infections, cirrhosis, and aflatoxin exposure, not typically with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option C. Gastric cancer: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, dietary factors, and genetic predisposition, not with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option D. Urinary bladder cancer: Often linked to smoking, occupational exposures, and Schistosoma haematobium infection (another type of parasitic worm), not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Humans acquire the infection by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing the metacercariae (infective stage).

 

Chronic infection leads to:

 

  • Inflammation
  • Hyperplasia of the biliary epithelium
  • Fibrosis
  • Malignant transformation → Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic is correctly matched with its site of action (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal tubule

 

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - These act in the proximal tubule. Acetazolamide is a commonly used carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics- Collecting duct: These work primarily in the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle, not the collecting duct. Mannitol is a common example.

 

Option C. Thiazides-Loop of Henle: These primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide is a typical example.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists- early Distal tubules: These work in the collecting ducts and late distal tubules. Spironolactone is a well-known aldosterone antagonist.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lateral medullary syndrome

 

The patient's presentation with loss of pain and temperature sensation from the left side of the face and the right side of the body, along with dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex, suggests involvement of the lateral medulla. Additionally, the presence of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) on the left side further supports this diagnosis.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The key clinical features include:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face due to involvement of the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysarthria and dysphagia due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX and X).
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the descending sympathetic pathways.
  • Ataxia due to involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pontine syndrome: Lateral pontine syndrome involves the pons and typically affects cranial nerves that are not involved in this patient's presentation. For example, it often involves the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), leading to facial weakness, which is not described in this case.

 

Option B. Medial medullary syndrome: Medial medullary syndrome affects the medial structures of the medulla, including the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), and results in ipsilateral tongue weakness and contralateral hemiparesis. This does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Locked-In Syndrome: Locked-In Syndrome results from bilateral lesions in the ventral pons, leading to quadriplegia and anarthria, but with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. The patient's symptoms do not align with this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity
  4. Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) presents with lowered serum iron levels, decreased transferrin saturation, elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and diminished ferritin levels.

 

1. Reduced Serum Iron

 

  • What it is: This is the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin in the blood.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, the body's iron stores are depleted due to chronic blood loss, poor dietary intake, or malabsorption, so there's less iron available to circulate.
    • Seen in IDA

 

2. Reduced Transferrin Saturation

 

  • What it is: This is the percentage of transferrin that is bound to iron.
  • Transferrin Saturation=Serum Iron​/TIBC×100
  • Why it decreases: Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, this ratio drops.
    • Seen in IDA

 

3. Increased Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)

 

  • What it is: This reflects the maximum amount of iron that transferrin can carry.
  • Why it increases: The liver increases transferrin production in an attempt to capture more iron from the gut when body iron is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

4. Reduced Ferritin

 

  • What it is: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron in cells and tissues.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, body iron stores are depleted, so ferritin levels drop.
  • Important point: Ferritin is also an acute-phase reactant and may be elevated in inflammation, but in pure iron deficiency, it is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

Summary Table

 

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

C. 1, 2, 3, 4 — all of these changes are classical features of iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the usual position of the Golgi apparatus in serous acinar cells? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supranuclear

 

Golgi complex is located in supranuclear cytoplasm in serous acinar cells. Serous acinar cells are generally found in pancreas and the submandibular salivary glands.

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi complex is involved in the modification and packaging of secretory proteins into vesicles that can be transported to the apical surface of the cell for release into the ducts or glands. The supranuclear location of the Golgi complex in these cells allows for efficient transport of these vesicles to the apical surface for secretion.

 

In contrast, other organelles such as the nucleus, mitochondria, and rough endoplasmic reticulum are typically located in the basal or perinuclear regions of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal: Incorrect, as the basal region is typically where the nucleus and other organelles like mitochondria are located.

 

Option C. Adjacent to nucleus: Incorrect, while the Golgi apparatus is near the nucleus, it is specifically located above the nucleus in the supranuclear position in serous acinar cells.

 

Option D. Apical: Incorrect, as the Golgi apparatus itself is not located in the apical region, though it directs secretory vesicles to this area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi apparatus is typically located in the supranuclear region, facilitating the modification and transport of secretory proteins for efficient secretion into the glandular ducts.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

In Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there is an increase in both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC). These changes occur due to air trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs, which are characteristic of COPD.

 

  • FRC (Functional Residual Capacity): The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. This increases in COPD due to air trapping.
  • TLC (Total Lung Capacity): The maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. It may be increased or remain normal in COPD due to hyperinflation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In COPD, both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC) increase due to air trapping and lung hyperinflation.

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Systemic lupus erythematosus

 

The clinical presentation of fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and the characteristic facial rash, often referred to as a "butterfly rash" due to its shape across the cheeks and nose, strongly suggests Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). SLE is an autoimmune disease that affects multiple organ systems and often presents with a combination of systemic symptoms and specific skin manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatomyositis: This condition is characterized by muscle weakness and a skin rash, but the rash typically appears on the eyelids (heliotrope rash), knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes (Gottron's papules), which does not match this presentation.

 

Option C. Rosacea: Typically presents with facial redness, small red bumps or pustules on the nose, cheeks, forehead, and chin, but lacks the systemic symptoms such as fever and oral ulcers associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Melasma: Mainly a condition of hyperpigmentation that affects sun-exposed areas and does not involve systemic symptoms like fever or oral ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:


When presented with a patient who shows systemic symptoms like fever and oral ulcers in combination with a characteristic facial rash and photosensitivity, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus should be considered a likely diagnosis. Confirmatory diagnosis would require additional clinical and serological criteria, including a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ SLE, Chap 356

questions.text: Meissner corpuscles are present in: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Papillary dermis

 

Explanation:

 

The papillary dermis is the uppermost layer of the dermis, lying directly beneath the epidermis. It is named so because of its projections called dermal papillae that interlock with the rete ridges of the epidermis.

 

These dermal papillae increase the surface area between the epidermis and dermis, allowing for better nutrient exchange and anchoring. Meissner corpuscles, also known as tactile corpuscles, are located in the papillary dermis, especially in areas sensitive to light touch, such as the fingertips and lips. They are oval-shaped mechanoreceptors that are sensitive to fine touch and low-frequency vibration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is the deeper and thicker layer of the dermis, located beneath the papillary dermis. It comprises mainly of dense irregular connective tissue containing collagen and elastin fibers. While it contains other structures like sweat glands, hair follicles, and blood vessels, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.

 

Option C. Basal epidermis: The basal epidermis, or stratum basale, is the innermost layer of the epidermis. It consists of a single layer of columnar or cuboidal keratinocytes. These cells are continuously dividing and pushing older cells upwards towards the skin surface. The basal layer also contains melanocytes, which produce the pigment melanin, and Merkel cells, another type of tactile mechanoreceptor. However, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.

 

Option D. Stratum lucidum: The stratum lucidum is a thin, clear layer of the epidermis, typically found only in areas of thick skin such as the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It lies between the stratum corneum (outermost layer) and the stratum granulosum. The stratum lucidum is made up of dead, flat keratinocytes that have a translucent appearance. Meissner corpuscles are not located in this epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanocyte are found in Stratum basale
  • Merkel cell found in stratum basale
  • Meissner corpuscles found in papillary dermis
  • Keratohyaline granules are found in stratum granulosum
  • Keratin is found in Stratum corneum & lucidum
     

 

Meissner corpuscles are found in papillary dermis, are enriched in the fingers and toes, and have an unmyelinated nerve terminal that is surrounded by Schwann cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient with a history of acute myeloid leukemia presents with persistent fever, cough, and shortness of breath despite broad-spectrum antibiotics. A chest CT scan reveals multiple nodular infiltrates with halo signs suggestive of fungal infection. The physician orders a serum galactomannan assay to aid in the diagnosis. Which condition is indicated by the presence of galactomannan in the serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Invasive Aspergillosis

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of galactomannan in serum is indicative of invasive aspergillosis, a serious fungal infection primarily affecting immunocompromised individuals, such as those with hematologic malignancies or undergoing stem cell transplantation. Galactomannan is a polysaccharide component of the Aspergillus cell wall, released during active fungal growth in the host. Detection of galactomannan in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a valuable diagnostic tool for early identification of invasive aspergillosis, allowing timely antifungal treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Candidiasis is caused by Candida species, which do not release galactomannan as a component of their cell wall. Diagnosis is usually made by blood cultures, biopsy, or other antigen detection methods specific to Candida, such as beta-D-glucan assays.

 

Option C. Cryptococcosis: Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus species, and its diagnosis relies on the detection of cryptococcal antigen in blood or cerebrospinal fluid. Galactomannan is not associated with Cryptococcus, and its presence does not indicate this infection.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus, and its diagnosis typically involves antigen detection in urine or serum, fungal cultures, and histopathological examination. Galactomannan testing is not used in diagnosing histoplasmosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detection of galactomannan in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is a key diagnostic marker for invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. This antigen detection test helps in the early diagnosis and management of invasive fungal infections, significantly improving patient outcomes when coupled with prompt antifungal therapy

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

choices.text: rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis
pLDH, Plasmodium malaria
Biopsy, Histoplasmosis
ELISA, HIV

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

 

This given clinical picture shows A and B. macrophage infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies (arrows) characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain) suggestive of Leishmaniasis which can be confirmed by the rk 39 antigen test.

 

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases: visceral (the most serious form because it is almost always fatal without treatment), cutaneous (the most common, usually causing skin ulcers), and mucocutaneous (affecting mouth, nose and throat).

 

Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

 

Following the discovery of a 39-amino acid residue (k-39) encoded by a kinesin-related gene in the amastigotes of Leishmania chagasi, it has been used in the format of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 

 

Immunochromatographic test (ICT) for detection of antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.1,4–6 Anti-k39 antibodies are secreted into various body fluids such as urine and sputum along with blood, and have been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (VL). rK39 strip test is rapid and a sensitive and specific indicator of visceral leishmaniasis(VL).

 

Parasitological methods of diagnosis remain the gold standard for diagnosing leishmaniasis. Diagnosis in the laboratory can be achieved by direct examination of amastigotes in giemsa-stained lesion smears of scrapping, biopsies, or impression smears.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. pLDH, Plasmodium malaria: Plasmodium malaria would present differently on a blood smear and would not typically show macrophages with intracellular organisms in a bone marrow sample. The pLDH test is specific for diagnosing malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Biopsy, Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis could cause fever of unknown origin and show organisms in macrophages, but the morphology would be different from Leishmania donovani. Histoplasma typically appears as small yeast forms within macrophages, not the double dot appearance seen here.

 

Option D. ELISA, HIV: While HIV can present with fever of unknown origin, it would not directly explain the bone marrow findings of intracellular Leishmania bodies. An ELISA test for HIV is not relevant to diagnosing the cause of the observed bone marrow pathology.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: As a healthcare consultant in Uttar Pradesh working to improve maternal and child health outcomes, you need to address issues such as inadequate hygiene, lack of skilled staff, and outdated equipment in labor rooms of public health facilities. Which program should you recommend that is specifically designed to enhance the quality of labor rooms? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) LAQSHYA

 

LAQSHYA [Labour Room Quality Improvement Initiative] 

 

  • MoHFW launched LaQshya to improve the quality of care that is being provided to the pregnant mother in the Labor Room and Maternity Operation Theaters, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth
  • Aim: To reduce Maternal and newborn mortality & morbidity and stillbirths
  • Coverage: Govt Medical colleges & hospitals/District hospitals/FRU > 100 deliveries/month, High load CHC (>60 deliveries/month)

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ayushman Bharat: This is a broader health insurance scheme aimed at providing health cover to underprivileged families, not specifically focused on improving labor room conditions.

 

Option C. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: Although this program provides free benefits to pregnant women and sick infants, it does not specifically target the improvement of labor room conditions.

 

Option D. Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This initiative is aimed at providing assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to pregnant women on the 9th of every month but does not specifically address labor room quality improvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recommending the LAQSHYA program is directly aligned with the need to overhaul the quality of labor rooms in public health facilities, targeting specific improvements in infrastructure, hygiene, and staff competencies to ensure safer childbirth experiences.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate brought to the outpatient department is found to have bilateral conjunctivitis. Chest X-ray done showed lung infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the infection? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the likely cause of the infection in neonatal conjunctivitis.
  • The infection usually appears 1 week after birth and is transmitted from the mother's cervix or urethra during delivery.
  • Symptoms include edematous conjunctiva, watery discharge that later becomes purulent or bloody.
  • Diagnosis involves taking samples from both the conjunctiva and oropharynx and examining them for intracellular inclusion bodies.
  • Treatment involves administering erythromycin ethylsuccinate 50 mg/kg daily in four divided doses before feeds for 2-3 weeks.
  • If left untreated, associated systemic diseases such as chlamydial otitis and pneumonia may develop later.
  • Both parents must receive appropriate treatment for genital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilus influenzae: This bacterium can cause conjunctivitis but is less likely to present with systemic involvement like pneumonia in the context of neonatal infection.

 

Option C. Streptococcus: While capable of causing neonatal infections, Streptococcus species are more commonly associated with other forms of neonatal morbidity such as sepsis or meningitis, rather than conjunctivitis with pneumonia.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: It is known to cause respiratory infections in older children and adults but is an uncommon cause of neonatal conjunctivitis or pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal conjunctivitis typically presents during the first month of life and the age of the neonate is an important clue to the infection's etiology.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation in infectious diseases, a patient with dengue fever develops warning signs like abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, clinical fluid accumulation, and an increase in hematocrit with a decrease in platelet count. Which of the following is the cornerstone of management for a patient showing warning signs of dengue? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) IV Fluids 

 

  • The mainstay treatment for patients with dengue showing warning signs is intravenous (IV) fluid therapy.
  • This approach is crucial to prevent progression to severe dengue, including dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: Only indicated if there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm³) with active bleeding.
