Option C. Cryoglobulins: Not relevant for dengue management.

 

Option D. FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): Not a primary treatment for dengue with warning signs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

A-3. Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living amoeba uses pseudopodia for locomotion.

 

B-2. Balantidium coli, is a ciliated protozoan (and the largest protozoan that infects humans)

 

C-1. Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, flagellated protozoan parasite.

 

D-4.Toxoplasma gondii is a member of the phylum Apicomplexa, a diverse group of intracellular parasites that share a unique form of gliding motility. Gliding is substrate dependent and occurs without apparent changes in cell shape and in the absence of traditional locomotory organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balamuthia mandrillaris: Uses pseudopodia for movement.
  • Balantidium coli: Uses cilia for locomotion.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis: Uses flagella for movement.
  • Toxoplasma gondii: Exhibits gliding motility, a substrate-dependent movement without the use of traditional locomotory organelles.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Neonate with complaints of paroxysm of cough followed by apnea and leucocytosis (>50,000 cells/ L) points to diagnosis of pertussis, for which DOC is Macrolides, i.e., Azithromycin.

 

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

 

A well appearing young child begins to choke, gasp and flail the extremities with face reddened. Apnea and cyanosis may follow the coughing.

 

 

Infants < 3 months do not display the classic stages of whooping cough. Catarrhal phase is usually unnoticed.

 

Treatment – Macrolides

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is not effective against Bordetella pertussis and is not used for the treatment of pertussis.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is an alternative treatment for pertussis in patients who cannot tolerate macrolides but is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: This antibiotic is not typically used for the treatment of pertussis and is not considered the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

choices.text: LH from maternal pituitary
HCG from placenta
Inhibin from corpus luteum
GnRH from fetal hypothalamus

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • HCG from placenta:
    • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus.
    • HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
    • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
    • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
    • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
    • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LH from maternal pituitary: Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.

 

Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum: Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.

 

Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus: GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.

 

Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 58-year-old diabetic man presents to the emergency department with facial swelling, black eschar on the palate, and blurred vision in his right eye. He has a recent history of sinusitis that has rapidly progressed despite treatment. Imaging reveals extensive sinus involvement and orbital extension. A fungal infection is suspected, and a biopsy confirms mucormycosis. Which component of the fungal cell wall is absent in this fungal infection, differentiating it from other common fungal pathogens?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Beta-1, 3-D-glucan

 

Explanation:

 

Mucormycosis is caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, including species such as Rhizopus and Mucor, which are characterized by the absence or minimal presence of Beta-1, 3-D-glucan in their cell walls. Beta-1, 3-D-glucan is a major polysaccharide present in the cell walls of most other pathogenic fungi, such as Candida and Aspergillus. Its absence in mucormycosis is clinically significant because diagnostic tests like the Beta-D-glucan assay, which detects this component, will not identify infections caused by Mucorales. This distinguishing feature is crucial for differentiating mucormycosis from other invasive fungal infections.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beta-1, 6-D-glucan: This component is found in the cell walls of many fungi, including Candida and Aspergillus, but its presence or absence is not a defining characteristic of mucormycosis. It is not specific to Mucorales and does not differentiate them from other fungi.

 

Option C. Galactomannan: Galactomannan is a polysaccharide found in the cell walls of Aspergillus species and is commonly used in the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis. However, it is not a component of Mucorales and is irrelevant in the context of mucormycosis, though its absence does not specifically define these fungi.

 

Option D. Alpha-glucan: Alpha-glucan is another structural polysaccharide found in some fungal species but is not specifically absent in mucormycosis. Its presence or absence is not used as a key differentiating factor in diagnosing mucormycosis compared to other fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis, caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, is distinguished by the absence or minimal presence of Beta-1, 3-D-glucan in its cell wall. This absence affects the accuracy of common fungal diagnostic tests, necessitating alternative diagnostic strategies for accurate identification and treatment of mucormycosis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Banana sign on USG associated with? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spina bifida

 

Spina bifida is a type of neural tube defect / spinal dysraphism which can occur to varying degrees of severity. It is often considered the most common congenital CNS malformation.

 

Banana sign - Refers to the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis, which appears elongated and curved, resembling the shape of a banana.

 

Lemon sign - In prenatal ultrasound, when spina bifida is present, the base of the skull can appear abnormal and shaped like a lemon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where abdominal contents protrude into the umbilical cord. This condition is associated with various ultrasound findings, but not specifically with the Banana sign.

 

Option C. Down’s syndrome: Characterized by the presence of an extra chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), Down’s syndrome has associated ultrasound markers like increased nuchal translucency and absent nasal bone, but not the Banana sign.

 

Option D. Klinefelter syndrome: A genetic condition affecting males, characterized by an extra X chromosome (XXY). This condition is typically identified through genetic testing and is not associated with the Banana sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Banana sign" on ultrasound is specifically associated with spina bifida and represents the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis. It is a critical ultrasound finding suggestive of spina bifida and should be carefully evaluated alongside other signs such as the "Lemon sign," which depicts an abnormal skull shape resembling a lemon, also indicative of neural tube defects like spina bifida.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic, hypertensive woman underwent a cardiac biopsy. Her histology image with special stain is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

 

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by abnormal diastolic filling with relatively preserved systolic function. The histology often shows increased myocardial stiffness due to fibrosis, which is evident as diffuse fibrotic deposition within the myocardium. The cardiac muscle appears normal in size or slightly hypertrophic without significant dilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Typically shows dilated heart chambers and significant myocardial thinning with fibrosis, which is not evident in the provided histology image.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Characterized by marked hypertrophy of the myocardium, especially the septum.

 

Option D. Atrial fibrillation: This is primarily an electrical disorder of the heart, typically not diagnosed via myocardial biopsy and does not have a distinctive histopathological appearance related to the rhythm disorder itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In restrictive cardiomyopathy, the key histological feature is myocardial fibrosis leading to stiffening of the heart muscle, which impacts its ability to fill properly during diastole, though systolic function might be preserved.

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis
Gangrenous necrosis
Fat necrosis

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrinoid necrosis

 

Immune responses that affect blood vessels, such in polyarteritis nodosa, typically display fibrinoid necrosis.

 

Grossly, PAN lesions appear as minute beaded nodules at the bifurcations and branching of vessel segments.

 

Antigen-antibody complexes accumulate in the blood arteries in several immunological diseases. Complement activation brought on by these complexes causes type III hypersensitivity, which damages cells. This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around the blood vessels.

 

Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized by deposition of fibrin-like material which has the staining properties of fibrin. It is encountered in various examples of immunologic tissue injury (e.g., in immune complex vasculitis, autoimmune diseases, Arthus reaction etc.), arterioles in hypertension, peptic ulcer etc.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gangrenous necrosis: Typically associated with ischemic necrosis of limbs or bowel, not primarily a feature of vascular inflammation.

 

Option C. Fat necrosis: Occurs in adipose tissue due to trauma or pancreatitis, not related to vascular injury.

 

Option D. Caseous necrosis: Characteristic of tuberculosis, involving granulomatous inflammation with a cheese-like appearance, unrelated to PAN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions:

 

  • SLE
  • Libman-sacks endocarditis
  • Arthus reaction
  • Serum sickness
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Malignant hypertension

questions.text: Phospholipase C acts via which of the following G protein-coupled receptors?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gq 

 

Phospholipase C acts via the Gq type of G protein-coupled receptors. It leads to the activation of the IP3-DAG pathway. The receptors that act via this pathway include the receptors of H1, α1, M1, V1, M3, Angiotensin II, Gastrin, GnRH, Oxytocin and TRH.


Important points about GPCR:

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times (heptahelical). Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go. GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

 

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and thus increase in cAMP.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and thus decrease in cAMP.
  • Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C which generates the second messengers inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). It helps in mobilizing Ca2+ form the endoplasmic reticulum stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, which in turn generate the second messengers IP3 and DAG, leading to various downstream effects, including the mobilization of calcium ions from intracellular stores.

questions.text: A young man sustained a scorpion sting 2 hours ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 154/94 mm Hg; Heart Rate 72 beats/minute, and respiratory rate 32 breaths/minute. He also complains of breathlessness. Which of the following is the preferred drug for management of this patient? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prazosin


Scorpion venom causes release of a large amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals which can lead to hypertension, tachycardia, breathlessness due to pulmonary edema etc. These effects are counteracted by using Prazosin, which is a selective α1 blocker.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Metoprolol: This is a beta-blocker used primarily for managing hypertension, heart rate control, and other cardiovascular conditions. It is not typically used in the management of scorpion stings, as it doesn't directly address the pathophysiological effects of the venom.

 

Option B. Ivabradine: This drug is used to reduce heart rate in certain conditions such as chronic heart failure and angina. It is not indicated for treating symptoms of scorpion sting.

 

Option D. Frusemide: This is a diuretic, primarily used to treat conditions like hypertension and edema. It does not have a direct role in managing the effects of a scorpion sting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the preferred drug for managing the symptoms of a scorpion sting, as it counteracts the effects of catecholamines released due to the venom, providing relief from hypertension and pulmonary edema. Other drugs listed do not directly address the primary pathophysiological effects of a scorpion sting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a persistent dry cough, sore throat, and mild fever for the past 10 days. She has no significant past medical history. Physical examination shows clear lung fields, and a chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrates indicative of atypical pneumonia. The clinician suspects Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection. Which class of antibiotics should be avoided due to Mycoplasma's inherent resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Beta-lactam antibiotics

 

Explanation:

 

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics because it lacks a cell wall, which is the target of these drugs. Beta-lactams, such as penicillins and cephalosporins, inhibit the synthesis of peptidoglycan, a crucial cell wall component in bacteria. Since Mycoplasma does not possess a cell wall, beta-lactam antibiotics have no effect. The treatment for Mycoplasma infections involves antibiotics that act on protein synthesis or DNA replication, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, or fluoroquinolones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Aminoglycosides: Aminoglycosides inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit. While not commonly used for Mycoplasma, they are not inherently ineffective against it based on the absence of a cell wall.

 

Option B) Sulfonamides: Sulfonamides act by inhibiting folic acid synthesis in bacteria. Mycoplasma does not inherently resist sulfonamides, but these drugs are not the primary choice for treating Mycoplasma infections due to their variable efficacy.

 

Option D) Glycopeptides: Glycopeptides, like vancomycin, inhibit cell wall synthesis by binding to D-alanyl-D-alanine termini of peptidoglycan. While effective against gram-positive organisms, they are ineffective against Mycoplasma due to the absence of a cell wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall, rendering it inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics, which target cell wall synthesis. Effective treatment options include macrolides, tetracyclines, and fluoroquinolones, which target bacterial protein synthesis or DNA replication instead.

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysplasia

 

The hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and intact basement membrane are all suggestive of dysplasia.

 

Dysplasia is characterized by the loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and their architectural orientation.

 

The features of dysplasia include:

 

  • Pleomorphism
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
  • Increased mitotic figures

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma: In carcinoma, there is the invasion of the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Metaplasia: It refers to the replacement of one cell type with another type. It is almost always associated with tissue damage, repair, and regeneration. The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous.

 

Option D. Hyperplasia: It refers to the increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ. It can be physiologic or pathological. Enlargement of the female breast during pregnancy is physiologic hyperplasia. Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of pathological hyperplasia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal cellular features such as pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic figures, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. It involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane, distinguishing it from carcinoma, which involves invasion beyond the basement membrane.

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given image shows characteristic features of Hymenolepis nana. This can be identified by its body segments being broader than long.

 

The egg of hymenolepis nana is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore with 6 hooklets as seen in the image. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

 

The scenario describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur after the administration of local anesthetics like bupivacaine. LAST can cause severe cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity, leading to symptoms such as seizures, coma, and cardiovascular collapse, as seen in this patient.

 

The management of LAST involves:

 

  1. Immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) if the patient is unresponsive and pulseless.
  2. Administration of 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid). This treatment, known as lipid rescue or lipid emulsion therapy, acts by creating a "lipid sink" that absorbs the local anesthetic from the tissues and blood, reducing its toxic effects on the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPR & Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It is used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker overdose.

 

Option C. CPR & Start Dobutamine infusion: While dobutamine can support cardiac function, it is not specific for treating local anesthetic toxicity and does not address the underlying cause.

 

Option D. CPR & Start NaHCO3 infusion: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis and certain poisonings, such as tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but it is not specific for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 years

 

  • The X-ray shows 7 Carpal bones. Thus, minimum age is 5 here.
  • Also, pisiform is not seen. Hence, the age is between 5-12.
  • The best answer is 7 years as the normal age range for appearance of pisiform is 8-12 years.

 

BONE AGE

 

  • Left hand and wrist X-ray PA view – most commonly used for bone age assessment – Based on appearance of carpal bones
  • First to appear is Capitate, then in a counter-clockwise fashion except pisiform which is the last carpal bone to appear
  • Pisiform is ossified at the age of nine to 13 years as evident from different studies.
  • The appearance of ossification center of pisiform bone is one of the important evidence for estimating age among young children between nine to 13 years.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.
